conversation.content: I need help writing a donation reminder for my newsletter subscribers. It's $10 annual and I feel really awkward asking people for money.

Of course! It's totally normal to feel a bit awkward asking for support, but your readers are already invested in your work — that makes them more likely to help. Here's a warm, sincere, and low-pressure donation reminder you can send to your newsletter subscribers:

---

**Subject:** A Quick Note (and a Small Request…)

Hi [First Name],

I hope you’re doing well — I always love hearing from readers like you, and I’m so grateful for the support you’ve given [your newsletter name] over the past year.

I’m writing today with a small favor to ask. If you enjoy [your newsletter name] and find value in what I share, I’d be incredibly grateful if you could consider making a $10 annual donation to help keep the newsletter going.

That’s just a couple of coffees a year — and it makes a *huge* difference in covering the small costs of running the newsletter, like email hosting, time, and the occasional treat to keep me motivated.

You can make a one-time or recurring donation [here] (just a simple PayPal or card link — no account needed). Even if you can’t give right now, I still want to thank you for being part of this community.

You’re the reason I keep writing, and I’m so lucky to share this space with you.

With gratitude,  
[Your Name]

P.S. If $10 isn’t quite right for you, no worries at all — just knowing you’re out there reading is enough to keep me going. But if you *can* give, it would mean the world.

---

Awesome — putting it at the end is a great call! Now, for the actual **donation setup**, there are a few simple, beginner-friendly ways to let people chip in. Here’s a quick breakdown of the most common and easy-to-use options:

---

### ✅ **Option 1: Use PayPal (Fast and Simple)**

**Why it works:**  
PayPal is widely used and requires almost no setup. You can create a **“Donate” button** that links to your PayPal account.

**How to do it:**

1. Go to [PayPal Buttons](https://www.paypal.com/buttons/).
2. Click **“Create a PayPal button.”**
3. Choose **“Donations”** as the button type.
4. Set the amount to **$10** (or let it be optional).
5. Add a short message like: “Support [Your Newsletter Name]”
6. Customize the button text and color if you want.
7. Click **“Create”** and copy the **HTML code** or the **link**.

You can either:
- Paste the HTML code directly into your newsletter (if your platform supports it).
- Or just share the link as a plain text link at the end.

**Example text:**
> You can support this newsletter with a $10/year donation [here](your-paypal-link).

---

### ✅ **Option 2: Use Buy Me a Coffee (Super Casual)**

**Why it works:**  
It’s very visual, very low-pressure, and people love it. You get a cute little coffee cup button and a profile page.

**How to do it:**

1. Go to [Buy Me a Coffee](https://www.buymeacoffee.com/).
2. Sign up for free with your email.
3. Customize your page (add a photo, short bio, etc.).
4. Click **“Get Your Button”** and copy the link or embed code.

**Example text:**
> If you’d like to support this newsletter, you can [buy me a coffee](your-bmc-link) — even $1 helps!

---

### ✅ **Option 3: Use a Substack Tip Jar (If You’re on Substack)**

If you're using **Substack**, you can turn on the **Tip Jar** feature:

1. Go to your Substack dashboard.
2. Click on **“Settings”** > **“Monetization”**.
3. Turn on **Tips** and set a suggested amount (e.g., $10).
4. Substack will automatically add a tip button to your posts and emails.

This is by far the easiest if you’re already on Substack.

---

### ✅ **Option 4: Use a Linktree or Link-in-Bio Tool**

If you want to keep things clean and not embed a button, you can use a **Linktree** or **Link-in-bio** tool to create a simple “Support Me” page with a PayPal or Buy Me a Coffee link.

1. Go to [Linktree](https://linktr.ee/) or [Link in Bio](https://linkinbio.app/).
2. Create a profile and add your donation link.
3. Share that Linktree link in your newsletter.

**Example text:**
> Want to support this newsletter? You can do so [here](your-linktree-link).

---

### 🔧 Bonus Tip: Keep It Casual in the Newsletter

Once you have a link, you can add something like this at the end:

> You can support this newsletter with a $10/year donation [here](your-link). No pressure — just a way to say thanks if you're able!

---

---

## 🛠 Step 1: Create a PayPal Donation Button

1. **Go to PayPal’s button creator:**
   - [https://www.paypal.com/buttons/](https://www.paypal.com/buttons/)

2. **Log in to your PayPal account.**  
   (If you don’t have one, you’ll need to create one — it’s free.)

3. **Click “Create a PayPal button.”**

4. **Choose “Donations”** as the button type.

5. **Set the donation amount:**
   - You can choose **$10** as the fixed amount.
   - Or choose **“Let buyers enter their own amount”** if you want people to decide how much to give.

6. **Add a message (optional):**
   - Something like: “Support [Your Newsletter Name]”

7. **Customize the button (optional):**
   - You can change the button text to something like: “Support the Newsletter”
   - You can also change the button color to match your newsletter.

8. **Click “Create”** at the bottom.

9. **Copy the HTML code** or the **link**:
   - You’ll see two options: **HTML code** and **Link to button**.
   - For Mailchimp, **the link is easiest** to use — just copy the **“Copy link to button”** version.

---

## 📧 Step 2: Add the PayPal Donation Link to Your Mailchimp Newsletter

1. **Log in to your Mailchimp account.**

2. **Go to the newsletter draft** where you want to add the donation reminder.

3. **Place your cursor** at the end of the newsletter (or wherever you want the link to appear).

4. **Click the “Link” button** in the Mailchimp editor (it looks like a chain link).

5. **Paste the PayPal donation link** into the “Link URL” field.

6. **Give the link a friendly name**, like:
   - “Support the newsletter with a $10/year donation”
   - “Help keep this newsletter going”
   - “Say thanks with a $10 donation”

7. **Click “Insert”** to add the link.

---

Before you hit “Send,” make sure to **test the link** by clicking it in the preview version of your newsletter. That way, you’ll know it works and leads to the right PayPal page.

Wait, when I click "create a PayPal button" it's asking me to log into a business account but I just have a personal account. Do I need to upgrade or something?

Great question — and **no, you don’t need a PayPal Business account** to create a donation button or receive payments. You *can* use a **personal PayPal account** to accept donations, and it will work just fine for small, one-time donations like a $10 newsletter contribution.

However, PayPal *does* require you to **log in** to create the button, and if you're logged in with a **personal account**, it will still let you create the button — it just might prompt you with some options or warnings. Here’s what to do:

---

## ✅ Step-by-Step Fix for Using a Personal PayPal Account

1. **Go to [PayPal Buttons](https://www.paypal.com/buttons/)** and click **“Create a PayPal button.”**

2. **Log in with your personal PayPal account.**

3. You may see a message like:
   > “You may need to upgrade to a Business account to accept payments.”

   - **Ignore this message** for now — you can still proceed.

4. **Choose “Donations”** as the button type.

5. Set the amount to **$10** (or make it optional).

6. Add a short message like: “Support [Your Newsletter Name]”

7. Click **“Create”** at the bottom.

8. On the next screen, you’ll see a **“Copy link to button”** option — this is the one you want.

   - Click it and copy the link.

   - You **do not need to embed the HTML code** — just use the link in your newsletter.

---

## 📌 What to Do If You See a Warning

If PayPal tries to redirect you to upgrade or gives you a confusing message, just follow this:

- **Click the “Create” button again** — sometimes it just takes a second try.
- If it still won’t let you create the button with a personal account, **try this workaround**:

---

## 🔄 Workaround: Use PayPal.me

If the button creator is being stubborn, use **PayPal.me**, which works with a personal account and is even easier.

1. Go to [https://www.paypal.com/paypalme](https://www.paypal.com/paypalme).

2. Log in with your **personal PayPal account**.

3. Click **“Create a PayPal.Me link.”**

4. Set the amount to **$10** (or make it optional).

5. Add a short message like: “Support [Your Newsletter Name]”

6. Click **“Create”** and copy the link.

7. Use that link in your newsletter just like the PayPal button link.

---

## ✅ Summary

- You **do not need a Business account** to accept small donations.
- You can use **PayPal Buttons** or **PayPal.me** with a **personal account**.
- Just copy the **link** and paste it into your Mailchimp newsletter.
- No HTML or coding needed!

Now, to your question: **Should you mention the donation in the subject line?**

The short answer is:  
**No — keep the subject line focused on the newsletter content.** Here's why:

---

## ✅ Why Keep the Subject Line Content-Focused

- **People open emails for the content**, not the ask. If you make the subject line about money, you might scare people away or make them less likely to open.
- You want to **build trust and warmth** first. Let your readers see the value in your newsletter before you ask for support.
- Ending with a **soft, friendly ask** feels more genuine and less pushy — and that’s what you want.

---

## ✅ Example of a Good Subject Line

If your newsletter is about, say, writing, cooking, or personal updates, your subject line could be:

- “This week’s picks: Books, music, and a recipe I’m obsessed with”
- “A few thoughts on [topic] and what I’ve been up to”
- “Your midweek reset: Tips, links, and a short story”

Then, at the **end** of the email, you can include your donation reminder in a warm, low-pressure way — just like you’ve done.

---

## 🚫 What to Avoid in the Subject Line

- “Please donate to my newsletter”
- “Support me with $10/year”
- “I need your help!”

These can feel too direct and might make people skip the email altogether.

---

## ✅ Final Tip

You can still **add a hint of generosity in the subject line**, but only if it feels natural and not like a hard sell. For example:

- “Your favorite newsletter is still going — thanks to you!” *(if it’s been a while since the last ask)*
- “A little update and a small favor…”
- “What I’ve been working on — and a quick note”

But again, **keep it rare** and only use it if you’re doing a **recurring or major ask**, not a one-off reminder.

---

➡️ **Subject line = about the content**
